your own words just introduce yourself, who you are and your involvement with the grant
living levels. Yes okay, well my name is Martin Bell and my day job is Professor of Archaeological
Science at the University of Reading. But for the last 38 years actually I've been doing
archaeological research in the seven estuary, originally on the English side at Breen Down
and then since 1991 on the Welsh side, particularly focused around Goldcliff where I've been looking
at sites dating from the Mesolithic period around 8,000 years ago right up to the end
of the Iron Age and we've excavated loads of sites and we're still working on the recording
of sites in that area. So when the Living Levels Project came along it was a really
great opportunity to convey some of the information that we've got out of all these years of work
on the archaeology of the foreshore of the seven estuary to a much wider audience and
to begin to train up local people in the sort of techniques which would enable them to record
sites in the future. So we've done a few training courses and we hope to do some more and we've
also had lots of lectures and we've helped Newport Museum with a new display on the archaeology
and helped the Newport Wetlands Centre with some archaeological material as well.
So when you were working on the other side of the estuary did you look across and think
right we've got to check that place out too?
Yes partly, that was it because the same deposits occur on both sides but actually the main
catalyst was a skilled steelwork technician called Derek Upton who worked at Glenwerne who
started finding lots of sites and told us about them and got us involved in investigating them
and he worked with us for many years, well these 10 years, guiding us around the site showing us
what he'd found and you know we're still plugging away really recording and investigating many of
the sites that he found as well as other sites that we've found since then but you know he played
a really important part in alerting everybody to the rich prehistoric archaeology of the seven
estuary along with a very different character, an academic geologist called John Allen who was a
colleague of mine at Reading University who sorted out the sedimentary sequence of the whole of the
seven estuary and was able to show that the deposits that Derek Upton had found wooden
structures and artifacts in were actually prehistoric. John Allen sadly died in the autumn
after a very successful career as a geologist.
